body.head.byline: By MICHAEL WILSON; Tanzina Vega contributed reporting.

A Queens woman returning home with her family after a day at Coney Island was killed early yesterday when a man drove through a red light and struck a livery van the family was riding in, the police said.

The man, Qadir T. Ahmad, 19, of Lake Grove in Suffolk County, was arrested at the scene and charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter, the police said. Neither he nor his two passengers, men ages 19 and 20, were injured.

The victim, Paula Serrano, 28, was holding her 20-day-old son, Arturo, in her lap when Mr. Ahmad's Toyota Camry struck the van, according to the police and members of her family. The baby and Mrs. Serrano's nephew, Rodrigo, 10 months old, and her sister, Maria, were being treated at Elmhurst Hospital Center yesterday, although the family did not know the extent of their injuries, said her brother, Eloy Coatl.

According to the family, there were seven adults in the van, including Mrs. Serrano's husband, Saturnino Serrano; Maria and her husband; Mr. Coatl and his girlfriend; and the livery driver. Besides the two babies, there was a third child in the van, Mrs. Serrano's 6-year-old daughter, Ana, who suffered minor injuries.

The accident occurred shortly before 2 a.m. at 65th Place and Queens Boulevard, as the van approached the family's home. Mr. Coatl said he saw the Camry coming, but there was no time to react. ''That car was speeding very fast,'' he said. ''We all screamed.'' Mrs. Serrano and the two babies were thrown from the vehicle, he said.

The accident was one of three over the weekend in which a woman was badly hurt or killed and someone was charged with driving while intoxicated. In Far Rockaway, a woman who was stepping out of her parked car on Saturday afternoon was struck by a car on Beach Channel Drive, the police said.
The driver, Kirk Blake, of West Hempstead, was charged with driving while intoxicated, and the woman remained in critical condition at Peninsula Hospital Center, the police said yesterday.

In the Bronx, Glenn Salera, 29, was arrested after he ran from the scene of an accident on the Cross Bronx Expressway on Friday, where his car had rear-ended a tractor-trailer, the police said; his passenger, Carmen Irizarry, was killed.

Well-wishers streamed into the Serrano family's apartment in Woodside yesterday, many of them too overcome with emotion to speak to reporters. A family friend, Oliverta Manzana, said of Mrs. Serrano: ''She's a good person. Always happy. We have no words.''
The family hopes to raise money to bury Mrs. Serrano in her native Mexico, Mr. Coatl said.
''She always took care of us,'' he said. ''She would cook for us, even though she had her two children.''
